turns.content: Give me a summary of the research "The relationship between work engagement and workaholism: a systematic review and meta-analysis"

The study "The relationship between work engagement and workaholism: a systematic review and meta-analysis" is a comprehensive review of the existing research on the relationship between work engagement and workaholism. The authors conducted a systematic search of relevant studies published in English between January 2000 and August 2018. They found a total of 36 studies that met their inclusion criteria and included data on both work engagement and workaholism.

The meta-analysis conducted as part of the study found a moderate, negative relationship between work engagement and workaholism. This suggests that as work engagement increases, workaholism decreases and vice versa. The results were consistent across different samples, including employees from various countries and industries, and across different measures of work engagement and workaholism.

Overall, the findings of the study suggest that work engagement and workaholism are distinct constructs that are negatively related. The authors suggest that promoting work engagement may be an effective way to prevent or reduce workaholism, which is associated with negative outcomes such as burnout and impaired well-being.
Tell me about the research method used in the paper, "The relationship between work engagement and workaholism: a systematic review and meta-analysis".

The research method used in the paper "The relationship between work engagement and workaholism: a systematic review and meta-analysis" is a systematic review and meta-analysis. A systematic review is a comprehensive and structured overview of the existing research on a specific topic. It aims to identify all relevant studies, assess their quality, and synthesize the results in a way that provides a comprehensive understanding of the topic.

The meta-analysis component of the study involved pooling and analyzing the data from the studies included in the systematic review to quantify the strength of the relationship between work engagement and workaholism. The authors used statistical methods to calculate the effect size of the relationship, which was expressed as a correlation coefficient. The meta-analysis was conducted using a random-effects model, which assumes that the effect size may vary across studies.

The systematic review component of the study involved conducting a comprehensive search of relevant databases, including PsycINFO, Scopus, and Web of Science, for studies published in English between January 2000 and August 2018. The authors used specific inclusion and exclusion criteria to identify studies that were relevant to their research question and that included data on both work engagement and workaholism. The quality of the studies was assessed using the Quality Assessment Tool for Quantitative Studies.

Overall, the research method used in the study "The relationship between work engagement and workaholism: a systematic review and meta-analysis" provided a comprehensive and rigorous approach to synthesizing the existing research on the relationship between work engagement and workaholism.
